Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Matthias> Like Duke said, from a hodler‚Äôs perspective we are looking at a coin swap, not an airdrop. If you ever decide to declare your crypto and mention the word airdrop, you might be subject to CGT. With coin swap, you‚Äôre all good.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> no idea what CGT is @Matthias

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> HUSH3 is a "swap", the old chain is abandoned. The "airdrop" is what I called the process of dispersing funds on our new mainnet, that is the process of sending funds. But technically going from HUSH v2 to HUSH v3 is a "swap". HUSH v3 is not like BTCH, which truly was an "airdrop", not a swap

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> And to clarify, our ticker has always been and will always be HUSH. Our "asset chain name" in the KMD system is HUSH3, because various things already knew HUSH, such as the iguana code that makes notarizations knew that HUSH had t1 addresses but HUSH3 has R addresses...

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Pixelised> @dukeleto  CGT means Capital Gains Tax on any profit made on investments...

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Pixelised> I'm no accountant but I can't see how CGT would apply when the old chain has been "abandoned" and migrated over to use KMD as an upstream code base.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @Pixelised @Matthias there is no CGT when given a fork coin or airdrop, I would make sure you both verify that before giving to your tax man. It depends which country you live, but it's when you go to fiat. Forks/airdrops fall under the law of when your cow gives birth in some place, no shit
